comments:
I20041112-gtk

I added a classpath variable to my source lookup settings in a launch config.
Then I got the exception below. Please dispatch to Core if you think that it's
not you...

The classpatch variable contained this string:

${ECLIPSE_HOME}/plugins/org.eclipse.motif_3.0.0/ws/motif

I am unable to reproduce the problem. Can you give steps?

ok, I do have steps:

1) on the Java>Build Path>Classpath Variables preference page: create a new
classpath variable as described in comment 0

-> note that when adding the variable, the dialog tells me that the "Path does
not exist", presumeably because it cannot resolve the used ECLIPSE_HOME variable?

2) open a runtime launch config dialog, select the 'Source' tab
3) press 'Add' to add a source lookup path
4) choose 'Java classpath variable' and select the variable created in step 1

-> a new entry is added to the list of source lookup paths
-> everything as expected so far

5) expand the variable

-> this is where I get the exception

Looks like it's just an invalid classpath variable - you were warned ;-)
moving to JDT Core for comment.

Actually it is not an invalid classpath variable, but a misused of JDT Core API.
JDT Debug is calling JavaCore#newLibraryEntry(IPath, IPath, IPath) with a
relative path "${ECLIPSE_HOME}/plugins/org.eclipse.motif_3.0.0/ws/motif" as the
first argument.

JDT Debug should check that the path is absolute before passing it to
newLibrary(...)

Moving to JDT Debug for comment

I am unable to reproduce. The dialog no longer allows me to add in invalid 
variable such as "${ECLIPSE_HOME}". I have to specify "ECLISPE_HOME", and then 
it works.
Reproducable with the steps given in comment 2 and 3.1-RC2. Reopening.

(In reply to comment #5)
> I am unable to reproduce. The dialog no longer allows me to add in invalid 
> variable such as "${ECLIPSE_HOME}". I have to specify "ECLISPE_HOME", and then 
> it works.

Darinw, which dialog are you referring to here?

Ah - from the buildpath page I can set the name to "${...}". However, I will 
have to test on Linux, as it still does not cause this exception on Windows.

Darin, you want to set the classpath variable name to TEST and its value to
${ECLIPSE_HOME}/plugins/org.eclipse.motif_3.0.0/ws/motif. Then add the classpath
variable TEST on the source lookup page. This should behave the same on any
platform since the path ${ECLIPSE_HOME}/plugins/org.eclipse.motif_3.0.0/ws/motif
is not absolute (it doesn't start with a slash).

traces.message: Assertion failed; Path for IClasspathEntry must be absolute
